snippet: Considering the triumphs of the U.S. women’s national team and the benefits of Title IX, one would think the National Women’s Soccer League would be a certain success. But two previous female soccer leagues have failed.
abstract: Juliet Macur Sports of The Times column argues that considering triumphs of United States women’s national soccer team and benefits of Title IX, National Women’s Soccer League would be a certain success; long-term viability of league, however, only in its second season, is already uncertain; holds that American women’s sports leagues cannot draw fans, either at live events or on television, at level of men’s leagues.
lead_paragraph: Considering the triumphs of the U.S. women’s national team and the benefits of Title IX, one would think the National Women’s Soccer League would be a certain success. But two previous female soccer leagues have failed.

headline.seo: Clinics Offer National Women’s Soccer League a Path to Success
headline.main: Women’s Soccer League Tries to Connect and Survive
headline.print_headline: Desperate League Looks to Connect in Order to Survive
